intro: Centropogon gesnerioides var. viperinus, commonly known as the viper's bugloss, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has opposite, narrow leaves that are often hairy, and it thrives in well-drained soils in full sun. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, known for its medicinal and ornamental uses. Its common name reflects the plant's association with venomous snakes, though it is not toxic to humans.
